Award.AwardTitle: CDS&E: Formalisms and Tools for Data-enabled Turbulence Modeling

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of the proposed research is to devise rigorous mathematical techniques that utilize large databases obtained by simulations to develop predictive models of turbulent flow. Even though the proposal is focused on turbulence, the tools to be developed will be of general applicability for data-driven modeling in other areas of science and engineering.

Predictive models have not yet taken full advantage of the massive amounts of data being generated by the fluids community. New strategies are needed to extract information and modeling knowledge from data. Adjoint-driven inverse problems will be invoked to extract relevant modeling information from data. An important aspect of this approach is that the data is processed in the context in which it is needed for prediction. Domain-specific machine learning techniques will be used to convert information to modeling knowledge. In essence, the inverse solution infers functional deficiencies in the model and machine learning is used to reconstruct the missing functional form. The co-PIs plan to investigate how to identify and formulate a properly-posed data-driven-turbulence-modeling problem, the implications that these approaches have in more general data-driven computational physics applications, and the most effective ways to use machine learning in a predictive physics setting. Applications to be explored include transition to turbulence, thermal transport, and near-wall turbulent stress closures. The proposed work is expected to result in improved closure models for Reynolds-Averaged as well as hybrid Reynolds-Averaged/Large Eddy simulations. While the focus of the proposed work is on turbulent flow applications, several aspects of the formulation and tools will be of more general value to the field of data-driven physical modeling. Educational activities that would integrate machine learning into fluid dynamics courses are proposed. Tools and technologies will be shared with the community and the industry

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the project was to identify opportunities and establish formalisms and tools for the advanced use of large scale data in the predictive modeling of turbulent flow. In this process, the following basic questions wereaddressed:(i) How to identify and formulate a properly-posed data-driven-turbulence-modeling problem? (ii) What implications do these approaches have in more general data-driven computational physics applications? and(iii) What are the most effective ways to use machine learning in a predictive physics setting?

This project was among the very first to be funded in the field of machine learning augmented turbulence modeling, and also among the first to be awarded in the broader area that is now referred to as scientific machine learning. Both of these are thriving areas now with hundreds of researchers. Two of the publications from this work have reached 250+ citations (on google scholar), and two review papers have been written.

The most important outcome of this project was to establish that physics-constrained learning can be formulated in a geometry agnostic fashion for complex problems. In other words, one can learn from a number of geometries and flow configurations, but can predict on completely different problems that share the same physics. This is different from classical system identification and data assimilation techniques which learn and predict on the same system. The paradigm titled "Field Inversion+Machine learning (FIML)" in the original 2016 Journal of Computational Physics paper demonstrated how one can train model-consistent machine learning models.

Following the fundamental developments in this project, the PI has been able to apply the developed research techniques in industry problems ranging from automobile aerodynamics to electro chemical modeling in Fuel cells. In all of these problems, the common thread is the FIML approach. 

This project, along with companion funding from the NSF in the form of a Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant, led to the creation of the center for data-driven computational physics at the University of Michigan, which has proved to be a focal point of data-driven modeling research, teaching and training at the university of Michigan.
